page.title: 13LOCAL HISTORY W. LEOMINSTER
page.content: During the Second World War one of the largest U.S. Military Hospitals in England was situated at Barons' Cross. Part of this site has now been built on with houses. The part of the hospital still remaining has been converted into a turkey farm. Buildings now converted to the only light industry in the area were once specially built hostels to accommodate Land Army girls, brought to work on the farms during manpower shortages of World War II. The Leominster-Kington railway line used to run through the area. This was closed to passenger traffic in 1955, and completely in 1964. Local farming used to be very labour-intensive, but machinery now mainly replaces this. Farmers who made their own cider partly paid farm labourers with cider.
